Review text: "When I plugged this into my computer I got a message saying there was a problem and I should scan it and fix it. It also didnt load quite right so I returned it and exchanged it for another one. I thought the Toshiba brand would be a quality item and I just got a dud. Unfortunately, the second one did the same thing saying it needed to be scanned and fixed, though it did open up. (I have a couple other different external hard drives and they work without a problem so its not a computer issue.) There was a pdf in it that was named 1 yr Standard Limited Warranty. I couldnt open it, though, because I wasnt authorized and it wouldnt allow me to delete it. So I sent that one back too and ordered a different brand."

Review text:
I'm primarily a Linux Mint OS user (for security purposes).  

On that OS I routinely back-up my Thunderbird Program (email client) using older external HDs.  

This device will not back-up that Thunderbird program - alerting me that the device does not support "Symbolic Links."  

These devices are made (the mfgs will tell you) for Windows OS's and possibly MACs, Androids, etc., but, NOT Linux Operating Systems.  

So, for my purposes this device is useless, and I've sent it back to Amazon!

This lead me to encounter an uncomfortable experience.  I  transferred some files but it took so long that I continued to work. When the drive stopped buzzing I assumed my files would be successfully transfered. Imagaine my horror when I did not see the files in the destination folder. I then went back to my source folder and did not see the files either. After some time past, I went back to the destination folder and sometimes would see the files. Why sometimes I dont know. I was concerned the files were lost so I did a search for the file by name and fortunately found them some times later."

He also suggests that if you don't subject them to extreme conditions, they can last for a long time.", "sentiment":"positive"}]

Review text: "Im not going to say if WD is the hard drive of choice for all, but its been my go-to for years now.  I use MANY internal/external hard drives and Ive had very good luck with most of them.  While i cant say how long any hard drive will last because much of it depends on how you use and handle it.  If you dont beat them up with dropping them or big temperature extremes Ive had my WD hard drives last me for over 10 years.  The internal drives tend to have a shorter life since they are subject to more intense use but even mine have lasted for well over 5 years or more of heavy use.  I have in use many 14, 16, 18tb size WD drives including this one in operation.  I disconnect my external drives when Im not using them since it will likely help them to last longer I believe.  The only WD external drives I had fail me were the 10tb, 12tb models so I would NOT recommend those sizes (failed very early on).  Another thing I like about these drives is I store a LOT of music and most other external drives like Seagate cannot keep up with the music data flow without breaks in the song while listening. WD has absolutely no problem keeping the music stream flowing without interruptions.  That alone is one of the best reasons to buy this brand external drive.  They generally handle some abuse such as being knocked over the the desk (while NOT running).  I dont know if it will remain undamaged if it falls over while running.  So far Ive never had that happen to find out.  Considering how many external drives I have from WD (mybook, elements, etc) they are a very stable and reliable drives.  You cant find a better price for the durability and quality you get in WD drives."

He also suggests that if you don't subject them to extreme conditions, they can last for a long time.", 'sentiment': 'positive'}
QA_Content: The user has mentioned that he has been using WD hard drives for over 10 years and they have lasted him well. He also suggests that if you don't subject them to extreme conditions, they can last for a long time.
Processed_QA_Content: I have been using WD hard drives for over 10 years and they have lasted me well. If you don't subject them to extreme conditions, they can last for a long time.
accept1: I have been using WD hard drives for over 10 years and they have lasted me well. If you don't subject them to extreme conditions, they can last for a long time.

Review text: Having bought a new "computer" WITHOUT as large a HD as I wanted ... this may have cost an arm and half a leg, but it has already made my computing ... tolerable. Review text: "I have been using this drive for about six months now and although it is great for backing up files, it totally sucks as a continually connected device. Anytime you click to access any file even when it is on a local SSD inside your computer it locks what you are doing until it can spin up, look for its directory, and then display it. This takes about five to fifteen seconds! If you are watching a movie that resides on this drive, the movie will lock up for several seconds several times during the movie as the computer goes to access the drive. So, I generally just copy the movie to my desk top, unhook the drive and watch it from the desktop. When I am not needing my backed up files, I disconnect the drive.  I just hate how slow it is. Ive been using SSDs for the past three years and for me to go back to an old tech spinning disk on a USB connection is just too slow for me. So, I just use it for backing up my files."

Review text:
On a Mac running Sonoma, this device provides the best backup experience I've ever experienced (with HDDs including a recent Canvio Flex that cost me 3 days of agony before I gave up in favor of this).

With 100k items changed, it took about 2 mins.

A total backup was about 20 mins, half that of on an HDD at least.

It seems to move 1Gb/sec from eyeballing it so far, and it's wonderfully small and lightweight, so I'm backing up more often from the ease of it all.

Review text: Wow the whole technology around external drives is very confusing. I used another top brand of external ssd with the same specs and its transfer rate was a crawl.30 mb/sec vs advertised 1,000 mb/sec !, Then I got the 2T Samsung and it transfers my 20mb pictures at an average of 300mb/sec. Now this is far from 1,000 mb/sec, but much faster than the competition. Upon further digging into the technology, I found that two usb drives used for the transfer , like ssd drive D transferring to ssd drive E, cuts your transfer rate by 50%. Then if you use an adapter for your cable, say style C to A, or a poor quality cable then you can lose an additional  30% in the transfer rate. So actual transfer rates depends on many factors, but based on my experience, I will only buy Samsung external ssd drives.

Review text: Wow the whole technology around external drives is very confusing. I used another top brand of external ssd with the same specs and its transfer rate was a crawl.30 mb/sec vs advertised 1,000 mb/sec !, Then I got the 2T Samsung and it transfers my 20mb pictures at an average of 300mb/sec. Now this is far from 1,000 mb/sec, but much faster than the competition. Upon further digging into the technology, I found that two usb drives used for the transfer , like ssd drive D transferring to ssd drive E, cuts your transfer rate by 50%. Then if you use an adapter for your cable, say style C to A, or a poor quality cable then you can lose an additional  30% in the transfer rate. So actual transfer rates depends on many factors, but based on my experience, I will only buy Samsung external ssd drives.

Review text: "Dive into the realm of ultra-high-definition videography with the SAMSUNG SSD T7 Portable External Solid State Drive, boasting a colossal 2TB of space. This isnt just an external drive; its a vault of speed and reliability, a perfect companion for your iPhone 15 Pros 4K ProRes video shooting prowess. Its the digital workhorse that videographers dream of  fast, robust, and with space to spare.", "But its not just about raw power. The portability of this SSD is a game-changer. With the T7, your 4K video endeavors are in safe, capable hands."

        }
Review text: Im not the most tech savvy and wanted backup on an external drive for graphics heavy work and photos.  I remember the challenge of making my last external drive compatible and especially deleting old files, so I was a little anxious trying to find a solution., In case it helps someone else, I work primarily on an iPad Pro in a design program (Affinity) and needed a backup storage solution besides the Cloud.  I didnt really want a second cloud solution to be backup and cant use an external drive with the iPad.  I also have a MacBook, which has massive storage, but cant be backed up to ICloud, while the ipad can backup to iCloud.  My workaround for immediate file saving is to create shared files which are stored on iCloud (I call them Desktop) on the ipad.  Desktop is stored on the hard drive of the MacBook and gets updated via ICloud device sharing even though I cant initiate an iCloud backup from the MacBook., Inside Desktop I have labeled files as usual and a parent file for graphic design from the Ipad, broken down into 100+ named project files and sub files.  Whenever I save from the ipad, I save to Desktop (in iCloud) and then choose the appropriate file within Desktop to save.  This way I have the folders on the hard drive of the MacBook as interim backup, and am working around not having iCloud backup storage available when Im on the MacBook.  The T7 comes in as secure and portable physical data storage., The T7 drive is the hard copy backup of the files shared between the iPad and MacBook, I think necessary in case of some dreadful software issue, fire, or other unanticipated loss of access.  I plan to have more than one as soon as I can afford it, to rotate., Again hopefully this may help someone like me who spent some solid hours figuring out a better way to secure my data and workaround the Mac user experience., Since I am wanted to do manual backups I needed the process to be easy so I wouldnt avoid doing them, for obvious reasons.  Though we dont need to get into it here I dont want to use Time Machine on my Mac to back up the disk.  So I had to figure out something else., The T7 is great, easy to use, no time at all to install, self explanatory pretty much.  I dragged folders full of work from the desktop (yes I like to see them, dont judge) to backup.  The initial backup was very quick and painless, most files were a few seconds.  The graphics heavy files perhaps took about 10 minutes?  These are massive, not a problem, and may have been quicker than this, I expected it to take more time.  (My last iCloud backup was over 13 hours of anxiety - I kid you not and have since deleted almost all the working files from the drawing app after saving them in Desktop so they happen more quickly now, but still, I thought this was a daylong project).,  I experimented with dragging an old file to the trash from the T7 disk pane, and it worked as expected.  I had to read online about how to go about copying my photos library (Mac) to disk, but it wasnt hard.  I have over 40,000 images, and it took about 20 minutes as I recall, if longer probably max 25.  I tested the backup by remaining in the open pane and opening the photo files, which worked.  Amazingly all this data barely touches the capacity of the drive, maybe 10% or less of a TB?  Minuscule, anyway.  2 TB is overkill for me, especially since old files can easily be deleted., (This may be different for a user in Time Machine because it keeps multiple versions of your backups, and maybe more settings etc. which can take up a lot of space?-  not tech savvy, as I said, but I had trouble with my older system and Time Machine and being unable to delete backups which rendered my backup disk unusable, and I didnt want to deal with this again even though its less convenient to do it manually)., I think the T7 drive will fail before I need more space, which is a great problem to have.  Im planning to get another disk (with less storage) and use it as a failsafe backup- ideally storing it in a safe or out of the house just in case, and keeping a rotation to protect against loss., On the critical end, Id love it and think it would be much safer for data if the user pane of the T7 was visibly different from the one on my desktop.  Its the same color, font, everything, as my desktop window (maybe thats just how these things work?), which makes me triple check when Im deleting or updating.  Dont do this on a Friday night after an adult beverage., Id also love it if there was a simple tutorial available when you opened the disk up, just for ease of first use, a how to  (experimented with a throwaway file deleting because it wasnt obvious that dragging files to the trash would work) for most, and as a reminder for others.  I hesitate getting one for my parents because of this.  But Im happy and will buy another, looking forward to the peace of mind it gives me.
Rephrased Snippets: {'feature': 'compatibility of external-hard-drives', 'actual_sentence_extracted': 'The T7 comes in as secure and portable physical data storage', 'rephrased_it(without experience & observation)': 'The user has mentioned that T7 external hard drive is secure and portable physical data storage.', 'sentiment': 'positive'}
QA_Content: The user has mentioned that T7 external hard drive is secure and portable physical data storage.
Processed_QA_Content: T7 external hard drive is a secure and portable physical data storage.
accept1: T7 external hard drive is a secure and portable physical data storage.

Review text: The SAMSUNG SSD T7 is blazing fast, with read speeds of up to 1,050 MB/s and write speeds of up to 1,000 MB/s. This means you can transfer large files, like movies and games, in seconds. I was able to transfer a 50GB file in less than a minute!, Compact and portable:, "The T7 is small and lightweight, making it perfect for taking on the go. Its about the size of a credit card, so it will easily fit in your pocket or bag.", Durable and rugged:, "The T7 is built to last. Its drop-resistant from up to 6 feet and is also water and dust resistant. This means you dont have to worry about it getting damaged if you accidentally drop it or spill something on it.", Stylish design:, "The T7 comes in a sleek and stylish design that looks great with any laptop or computer. Its available in three colors: black, red, and blue.", Easy to use:, "The T7 is plug-and-play, so you dont need to install any software to use it. Just plug it into your computer and youre good to go.", Security:, "The T7 comes with AES 256-bit hardware encryption to help keep your data safe. This means that even if someone loses your drive, they wont be able to access your data without the password.", "Overall, the SAMSUNG SSD T7 is an excellent portable SSD. Its fast, durable, and stylish, and its easy to use. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a great way to store their data on the go.", Here are some additional positive things to mention about the T7:, It comes with a three-year warranty., "Its compatible with PC, Mac, and Android devices.", It includes two cables: USB Type-C to Type-C and USB Type-C to Type-A., "Its energy efficient, so it wont drain your battery."

Review text:
On a Mac running Sonoma, this device provides the best backup experience I've ever experienced (with HDDs including a recent Canvio Flex that cost me 3 days of agony before I gave up in favor of this).

With 100k items changed, it took about 2 mins.

A total backup was about 20 mins, half that of on an HDD at least.

It seems to move 1Gb/sec from eyeballing it so far, and it's wonderfully small and lightweight, so I'm backing up more often from the ease of it all.

I just wish they came in even bigger capacity.

My 5tb drive is nearly full."

Review text: "I purchased this in August of 2022. At first, there were absolutely no problems. Then, in January of 2024, five months after the one-year warranty ended, it died. No power. Nothing. I had only used this a few times to store video files. I tried a different computer and a different cable, but neither worked. I did not purchase extra data recovery, since I thought Seagate products would last quite a while. To their credit, Seagate did give me an exception and is allowing me to return the device and they will see if they can recover the data at no charge. Whether they can remains to be seen. Ive had other external drives, (Buffalo and LaCie), that had no problems at all and lasted years. Im very disappointed in this device, though I do want to acknowledge that Seagate IS trying to help."

I am using it on my Windows otherwise I would return it for false advertising.  Here is the quote:, "Your Backup Plus Desktop is formatted as NTFS for compatibility with Windows out of the box. Therefore, you can connect Backup Plus Desktop to a Windows PC without formatting the hard drive. However, NTFS is not fully compatible with Mac computers. If you want to connect Backup Plus Desktop to a Mac as well as a Windows PC, you can install special software that allows Macs to read and write files to NTFS hard drives similar to Windows PCs. For details and instructions, see our dedicated support page for the Paragon driver for Mac."

Review text: Been through a few ssd external drives that promise from 800-2000MB speeds and while they test good on speed tests actual r/w speeds on say 4-15gigabyte files in a batch and the speed drops real quick to around less than100MB and they will heat throttle. Also there is a risk that writing is not complete from when linux says it is. Needless to say i was fed up especially risking my backup rom/iso storage on external ssds., This old school spinny hdd external drive is the real mvp people take for granted. Linux speeds were a solid 150-170MB writing through a questionable usb 3 port on my old pc for a constant 2tb transfer dump. Heat was only slightly warm and feels infinitely more reliable than a burning external ssd that heat throttles down hard. Most importantly after writing finished in the file manager. Hitting safely eject , actually ejected it within a few seconds as opposed to solid state transfers which need to "finish writing" for a undetermined amount of time., Best for storage of stuff that you wont be writing much to besides the first time like records or games/isos/roms/movies etc. Emulators can be set to read from drive directly., Not good for large dynamic file changes needing to be constantly saved or modified like video editing etc. Or extreme recording speeds needed in real time like some cameras., "Ideally this shouldnt be moving much from a stationary position since again we have a physical spinning hard drive inside.", "10/10 has its own purpose and superiority over ssds in my opinion and is more reliable long term since heat can easilt destroy a external ssd while these types of drives have a proven history of performance and reliability.", Also wd>seagate lol

Review text: Been through a few ssd external drives that promise from 800-2000MB speeds and while they test good on speed tests actual r/w speeds on say 4-15gigabyte files in a batch and the speed drops real quick to around less than100MB and they will heat throttle. Also there is a risk that writing is not complete from when linux says it is. Needless to say i was fed up especially risking my backup rom/iso storage on external ssds., This old school spinny hdd external drive is the real mvp people take for granted. Linux speeds were a solid 150-170MB writing through a questionable usb 3 port on my old pc for a constant 2tb transfer dump. Heat was only slightly warm and feels infinitely more reliable than a burning external ssd that heat throttles down hard. Most importantly after writing finished in the file manager. Hitting safely eject , actually ejected it within a few seconds as opposed to solid state transfers which need to "finish writing" for a undetermined amount of time., Best for storage of stuff that you wont be writing much to besides the first time like records or games/isos/roms/movies etc. Emulators can be set to read from drive directly., Not good for large dynamic file changes needing to be constantly saved or modified like video editing etc. Or extreme recording speeds needed in real time like some cameras., "Ideally this shouldnt be moving much from a stationary position since again we have a physical spinning hard drive inside.", "10/10 has its own purpose and superiority over ssds in my opinion and is more reliable long term since heat can easilt destroy a external ssd while these types of drives have a proven history of performance and reliability.", Also wd>seagate lol

Review text: We are advancing further into the information era and having to put up with moving parts in an electronic device is antiquated at this point. Many times ive had a hard drive brick on me because the portable device fails to resist the risk in portability: impact. If you want a portable storage, do not skimp out on SSD (or better yet PCIE SSD) or you putting your data at big risk with these miniature hard drives that fail from a fall or sharp impact. Twelve years ago, sure it was very tempting. But today you have options. The SanDisk Extreme Portable SSD looks pricey but it is worth every penny compared to a miniature hard drive that is likely to fail and cost you either more money in replacement parts or a pricey recovery service. This hard drive is very difficult to replace in parts. If it failed from corruption, recovering the data through software is so much more unlikely than with an SSD., The process of replacing parts is very difficult because the replacement parts are almost non-existant. Even used offers are not worth it because the low availability make them pricey. The process of replacing the parts is very meticulous and requires a strong T6 screwdriver head. If you buy low brand it will get stripped. If thats too much trouble, recovery service can be very pricey. If you want it done right, youre looking at data recovery outlets price gauging for $700 to $2,500. Such as "Drive Savers Data Recovery" (recommended by Linus Tech Tips). If you need portability buy an SSD. Or set up a NAS with a bunch of new hard drives you wont ever touch but are easy to repair.

Review text: Been through a few ssd external drives that promise from 800-2000MB speeds and while they test good on speed tests actual r/w speeds on say 4-15gigabyte files in a batch and the speed drops real quick to around less than100MB and they will heat throttle. Also there is a risk that writing is not complete from when linux says it is. Needless to say i was fed up especially risking my backup rom/iso storage on external ssds., This old school spinny hdd external drive is the real mvp people take for granted. Linux speeds were a solid 150-170MB writing through a questionable usb 3 port on my old pc for a constant 2tb transfer dump. Heat was only slightly warm and feels infinitely more reliable than a burning external ssd that heat throttles down hard. Most importantly after writing finished in the file manager. Hitting safely eject , actually ejected it within a few seconds as opposed to solid state transfers which need to "finish writing" for a undetermined amount of time., Best for storage of stuff that you wont be writing much to besides the first time like records or games/isos/roms/movies etc. Emulators can be set to read from drive directly., Not good for large dynamic file changes needing to be constantly saved or modified like video editing etc. Or extreme recording speeds needed in real time like some cameras., "Ideally this shouldnt be moving much from a stationary position since again we have a physical spinning hard drive inside.", "10/10 has its own purpose and superiority over ssds in my opinion and is more reliable long term since heat can easilt destroy a external ssd while these types of drives have a proven history of performance and reliability.", Also wd>seagate lol

Review text: "I recently got my hands on the FUNLAB Switch Game Case for my Nintendo Switch games and micro SD cards, and I have to say, its a total game-changer! As a die-hard Pokemon fan, the Pokedex Red design immediately caught my eye.", "First off, lets talk about storage. This case is a total beast when it comes to mass storage. It can hold up to 48 Switch game cards and 48 micro SD cards simultaneously. Can you believe that? Its a dream come true for someone like me who loves to have all their games in one place. No more searching around for lost cartridges or missing memory cards!", One thing that really stood out to me is the comprehensive protection this case offers. The exterior is made from a sturdy and water-resistant material, ensuring that my precious game collection stays safe and dry. The soft silicone slots inside are a stroke of genius. They are designed to hold the game cards securely in place, so I never have to worry about them slipping out or getting damaged. It really gives me peace of mind knowing that my games are well-protected., "I also appreciate the minimalistic magnetic closure. Its so smooth and effortless, making it a breeze to open and close the case. And thanks to the magnetic closure, I can say goodbye to any worries about my game cards falling out by accident. Its a small detail, but it makes a big difference in my daily gaming routine.", "Another feature that I find super convenient is the finger arc design of each card slot. It might not seem like a big deal, but trust me, it makes popping the cards in and out so much easier. The arc fits my finger perfectly, making the whole process a breeze. Its small details like this that make me realize how well thought out this case really is.", "Last but not least, the nostalgia factor is off the charts with this case. The beautiful red scheme and Pokedex design take me right back to my childhood. Its like a little nod to the hardcore gaming fan in me. I love showing it off to my friends and reliving those gaming memories while protecting my valuable collection.", "Overall, the FUNLAB Switch Game Case is a must-have for any Nintendo Switch owner, especially if youre a Pokemon fan like me. Its durable, practical, and has that extra touch of nostalgia. This case has truly changed the game for my gaming organization, and I couldnt be happier with it. Five stars all the way!"

Review text: I purchased the drive with an immediate need to write almost 5TB to the drive. I noticed at first it was writing at speeds above 100mb/s, which was fine even though the drive advertised itself as USB 3.1. But as it filled up I noticed it began to slow down to about 60mb/s. As other reviews have mentioned the included cable should not be used with this as write speeds are limited to 30mb/s and there are some fitment issues with the connector itself, interestingly the cable is capable of 350+mb/s when attached to a Samsung T5 SSD. Overall it feels solid, but this drive offers nothing special over other portable hard drives other than a USB-C port. I would rather spend more money on an SSD or save money if there are cheaper 5tb drives. To fill or copy the whole drive would take at least 15hrs.

Back up drive for Mac mini.

Review text:
I purchased this Western Digital "My Passport" portable hard drive to use on my rather old 2016 MBP.

I use this on my 2023 MBP as well and have both running same software and apps both synched .

I am a part time photographer and  have used Apple products for over ten years and appreciate the durability of their units .

I also have a NAS system with WD hard drives that are over 5 years old that I rely on for redundancy.

Review text:
This drive is not compatible with Time Machine.  

Ever since the new Ventura OS is will not work.  

I have tried countless things.

Support is not easy to navigate, nothing works.

I turned it in for a new drive thinking maybe I just got one with a glitch and now the new one does not work either.

Even with Apple Care support.

They should not sell it for Mac.

I have NEVER had this much trouble using an accessory.

It is beyond frustrating.

Review text: I was very nervous about the install on this WD external hard drive based on several reviews I read. I did not use the wire connection that came with the drive because too many reviews said it was cheap or it didnt work properly. I used a USB-C to USB-C connector since my iMac has the port for it. My intention for this drive was to use it as a Time Machine backup. With the computer powered off, I connected the drive to my computer. Then I powered the computer on and logged in. The message that popped up was to the effect of Do you want to use My Passport for Mac as a backup for Time Machine? I clicked to use it as an automatic backup for Time Machine and it did its thing! I will update if the drive fails or if other problems arise. I did not have to load any WD software, etc. My computer does not hold any sensitive info nor is it partitioned so this was a basic install.

Review text: Data Transfer Speed/Read:, 220mbps to 270mbps (Type-C to Type-C only) Fastest Transfer and Read Speeds {4K Ultra HD Support}, 6mbps to 34mbps (Type-C to USB only) Slowest Transfer and Read Speeds {Not For Ultra HD Content}, Size: 10TB (9.09TB Usable), Type: Mechanical (7200RPM), Purchase Date: September 11th, 2023 (day after my birthday lol, it was my birthday gift from my folks), It is somewhat noisy as it does make a lot of sounds which is normal for External HDDs however the knocking seems to be fairly normal as well for this specific External HDD as lot of others I read also seem to have knocking sounds., I would heavily advise using Type-C to Type-C if you want faster transfer speeds however keep in mind not PCs support Type-C to Type-C Connections as older models likely will not and not all will support 220mbps to 270mbps data transfer speeds as it heavily depends on your PCs Type-C Port. (I learnt this recently from connecting it through USB to my Laptop then through Type-C which I have personally found that Type-C is significantly faster), 4K Ultra HD requires a reading file speed of 30mbps or faster and it must be continuous so do not try to watch 4K Ultra HD content unless you use the Type-C to Type-C connection only as the other method will not be fast enough nor steady enough to support Ultra HD content., I have bought the 10TB one and it does make some knocking sounds when being used or just out of the blue like when not in use which is rather alarming as knocking sounds are typically bad with External HDDs however it has been fairly solid for me., I use the Type-C to Type-C cord that comes with it and I get an average speed of around 220mbps to 270mbps which is rather fast for an External HDD however I do frequently get that I/O Device error message which can be frustrating especially when trying to transfer over files (it is fairly rare I get that message however)., This device does not always show up on my 2019 Acer Predator Helios 300 and sometimes I have to plug it into my Xbox Series X to get it to work then I can unplug it and plug it back into my 2019 Acer Predator Helios 300 then it shows up as "External HDD (E:)" however it does not always stay active on my laptop and does occasionally disconnects itself then reconnects sometimes later. (Moderate chance but does resolve itself somewhat quickly) It has never disconnected from my Xbox Series X yet however, I put yet as one may never know in the future and I've only had this HDD for about a month

Review text: "To give you guys an idea of what a working hard drive means to me, I am a YouTuber with ~100k subscribers. Its like a mini-business, with a fair amount of cash earned from YouTube partnership. As a result, I need a good amount of extra storage space and substantial reliability, though I also need a good price. I thought I found the perfect combination of all of those things with the UnionSine 8TB External Hard Drive. While it worked decently enough at first, though was so noisy that even non-tech-savvy people noticed and thought there may be an issue with it, I was assured by the directions including in with the hard drive that such loud noise was supposed to happen.", "For three months, I was able to stream data with no issues straight to the hard drive at a high rate, sometimes capturing hours of 2K quality footage in a single day. Then, right when I was about to release arguably my biggest video in months, the hard drive failed. I went to sleep right after I finished the video with the idea that I could just upload it in the morning, but I could not have been more wrong. I turned my computer and external hard drive on, and it sounded substantially different than normal, as though it is no longer turning. It even made my computer turn on and shut off SUBSTANTIALLY slower, which is noticeable as I have an SSD that I use for my OS. It was giving my computer such fits that my computer wouldnt shut off until I removed the USB plug from it that was attached to the UnionSine external hard drive on the other end. Turning on my computer took approximately 10x as long as normal. I tested it to see if it was the failed UnionSine hard drive that was giving it fits, so I booted and shut off my computer WITHOUT the UnionSine external hard drive connected, and it turned on and shut off as normal.", "In short, I absolutely DEPEND on a quality hard drive that works and can store a good amount of data. This hard drive failed when I needed it most, and I hardly had 25% of the hard drive filled with data. I was probably hovering around 6TB free when it failed, which, along with how quickly it took for this to fail, is incredibly shocking. Meanwhile, I have an EXCELLENT 5TB Western Digital Black external hard drive that is over a year older than the UnionSine, and it still works like clockwork, and I have NEVER had an issue with it, or another, smaller version of that same WD Black external hard drive that I purchased years before that. Worse yet, I dont even move the UnionSine external hard drive, it stays in the same spot as it has since I first operated it.", I would recommend ANYONE that needs to have reliable storage stay away from UnionSine. Mechanical hard drive technology is DECADES OLD, and has NO EXCUSE for breaking within months of usage, especially within so much free space still left on it. Avoid this brand like the plague, and go for a more reputable brand, like Western Digital or Seagate.

Review text:
It seemed like a perfectly fine hard drive at first, it had a couple connection issues but nothing terrible.

After about three months of using it, it started to take forever to connect.

I tried everything to clean up my files to Defraggler, but it still takes upwards of 30 minutes to open one folder.

I barely had anything in it either, I used maybe 15gb MAX.

I would wait 30 minutes to open one folder, and then would have to wait another 30 for anything in that folder to load.

Review text: I have used Somnambulist externals and USB sticks in the past.  They were good, quality items.  That is why I bought this item. Well, this thing has Somnambulist printed on it, but it is clearly a counterfeit unit.  First of all, the federally REQUIRED FCC specifications label is NOT on it.  Secondly, the plastic casing is low quality.  Finally, I used it for 2 weeks and was very careful about storing it in the hard case. I never dropped it or abused it in any way. Review text: Title: A Tough and Trustworthy Companion for On-the-Go Storage Needs, The SanDisk Professional 5TB G-DRIVE ArmorATD is a rugged and durable portable external hard drive that packs a powerful punch when it comes to reliable storage on the move. Designed to withstand the rigors of adventurous lifestyles and demanding work environments, this external drive delivers on its promise of providing robust data protection without compromising on speed and accessibility., "Right out of the box, the ArmorATDs sturdy build and rugged design give a strong first impression. Its shock-resistant exterior, built to military-grade specifications, instills confidence that your valuable data is well-guarded from accidental drops and bumps. The IP55-rated water and dust resistance further adds to its resilience, making it an ideal companion for outdoor excursions, fieldwork, and other unpredictable scenarios.", "Performance-wise, the ArmorATD does not disappoint. With a capacious storage capacity of 5TB, it offers ample space for backing up large files, multimedia projects, and critical data, making it suitable for creative professionals, photographers, and videographers alike. The drives fast transfer speeds ensure efficient data management, even when handling hefty files, ensuring you dont waste precious time waiting for data to be copied.", The inclusion of both USB-C and USB-A compatibility ensures seamless connectivity with a wide range of devices, from modern laptops to older computers, providing versatile usage options for various workflows. Moreover, the drive is bus-powered, eliminating the need for an external power source and making it a truly portable solution., One notable feature of the ArmorATD is its compatibility with the SanDisk SecureAccess encryption software, offering added protection for sensitive data. This feature provides an extra layer of security and peace of mind for users concerned about data privacy., "Although the ArmorATD excels in many aspects, its worth noting that its rugged build makes it slightly bulkier and heavier compared to regular external drives. However, this is a necessary trade-off to achieve its exceptional durability.", "In conclusion, the SanDisk Professional 5TB G-DRIVE ArmorATD stands as a reliable and resilient external hard drive that caters to the needs of professionals, adventurers, and anyone seeking a trustworthy solution for on-the-go data storage. Its rugged design, generous capacity, fast transfer speeds, and secure data encryption make it a smart investment for safeguarding your valuable data, wherever your journey takes you. Whether youre trekking through the wilderness or working on intensive multimedia projects, the ArmorATD is ready to serve as your datas sturdy fortress."

QA_Content: The reviewer mentioned that the external hard drive has fast transfer speeds and ensures efficient data management, even when handling hefty files.
Processed_QA_Content: The external hard drive ensures efficient data management with fast transfer speeds, even when handling hefty files.
accept1: The external hard drive ensures efficient data management with fast transfer speeds, even when handling hefty files.

Review text: "Being a parent and the designated photographer for my daughters high school cheer squads, I was inundated with a deluge of high-resolution photos that demanded substantial storage and a swift, reliable solution for processing and post-production. This specific need led me to the SanDisk Professional 5TB G-DRIVE ArmorATD.", "To begin with, the G-DRIVE ArmorATDs USB-C connectivity was the perfect answer to my speed concerns. The drives high transfer rates were instrumental in uploading gigs of photos at a time - a task it performed without any hitch. As a Mac user, compatibility was a breeze, and I was pleased to find the drive integrated smoothly with my computer.", Furthermore, I use Adobe Lightroom for my post-processing requirements. With the SanDisk Professional G-DRIVE, the read/write speeds were impressive, helping to speed up my workflow significantly. The drive proved robust enough to handle the demands of heavy editing, even with multiple large RAW files., On top of its performance, I was immediately struck by the solid, rugged construction of the drive. The G-DRIVE ArmorATD is built like a tank and gives a sense of reliability. Knowing that this drive is designed to resist shock and survive a reasonable amount of wear and tear puts me at ease, especially considering the precious memories it houses., "The convenience of having a single cord for power and data transfer, provided by the USB-C cable, cant be overstated. The single-cable design means less clutter, more straightforward connectivity, and one less thing to worry about losing or forgetting at a crucial time.", In conclusion, the SanDisk Professional 5TB G-DRIVE ArmorATD has checked all my boxes for an external storage solution. It is fast, durable, and ideally suited for high-volume photography and post-production work. I wholeheartedly recommend it to photographers looking for a dependable and swift external drive solution.

Review text: After a mere two months of sporadic use, I encountered severe issues with my hard drive, which have left me incredibly frustrated. Specifically, the device is no longer being recognized consistently, despite my best efforts to troubleshoot and rectify the problem. This is an especially significant issue for me, as I had a substantial amount of content stored on the device that I feared was irretrievable. However, thanks to my knowledge of data recovery methods and a resourceful online community, I was able to restore the lost content and transfer it to a more reliable drive., I also attempted to perform a complete erase of all data on the device to restart it and potentially resolve the recognition issue. While the erase seemed to be successful at first, it was short-lived, and the device quickly returned to its original state of not being recognized. This has been a disappointing experience for me, especially given that I had opted to invest in a higher-end hard drive, believing that it would be a more dependable and long-lasting choice., "Its worth noting that hard drives are essential components of any computer system, used to store all manner of important data, ranging from personal documents to business records. As such, its crucial to choose a hard drive that can provide the reliability and durability necessary to safeguard your information. In particular, its essential to consider the type of hard drive youre purchasing, as well as its capacity, transfer speed, and overall performance.", For example, one key factor to consider when selecting a hard drive is its type, with the two primary options being solid-state drives (SSDs) and hard disk drives (HDDs). SSDs are known for being faster, more durable, and less susceptible to damage from physical impacts, making them an excellent choice for users who need high-speed data access or are frequently on the move. On the other hand, HDDs typically offer higher storage capacities at a more affordable price point, making them a more practical choice for users who require vast amounts of storage space for their data., "In conclusion, my experience with my recent hard drive purchase highlights the importance of carefully considering the features and specifications of any storage device youre considering. While a higher-end device may promise superior performance, its crucial to evaluate its reliability and durability, and weigh these factors against the cost to determine the best value for your needs."

With the SanDisk Professional G-DRIVE, the read/write speeds were impressive, helping to speed up my workflow significantly. The drive proved robust enough to handle the demands of heavy editing, even with multiple large RAW files., On top of its performance, I was immediately struck by the solid, rugged construction of the drive. The G-DRIVE ArmorATD is built like a tank and gives a sense of reliability. Knowing that this drive is designed to resist shock and survive a reasonable amount of wear and tear puts me at ease, especially considering the precious memories it houses., "The convenience of having a single cord for power and data transfer, provided by the USB-C cable, cant be overstated. The single-cable design means less clutter, more straightforward connectivity, and one less thing to worry about losing or forgetting at a crucial time.", In conclusion, the SanDisk Professional 5TB G-DRIVE ArmorATD has checked all my boxes for an external storage solution. It is fast, durable, and ideally suited for high-volume photography and post-production work. I wholeheartedly recommend it to photographers looking for a dependable and swift external drive solution.

Review text: Title: A Tough and Trustworthy Companion for On-the-Go Storage Needs, The SanDisk Professional 5TB G-DRIVE ArmorATD is a rugged and durable portable external hard drive that packs a powerful punch when it comes to reliable storage on the move. Designed to withstand the rigors of adventurous lifestyles and demanding work environments, this external drive delivers on its promise of providing robust data protection without compromising on speed and accessibility., "Right out of the box, the ArmorATDs sturdy build and rugged design give a strong first impression. Its shock-resistant exterior, built to military-grade specifications, instills confidence that your valuable data is well-guarded from accidental drops and bumps. The IP55-rated water and dust resistance further adds to its resilience, making it an ideal companion for outdoor excursions, fieldwork, and other unpredictable scenarios.", "Performance-wise, the ArmorATD does not disappoint. With a capacious storage capacity of 5TB, it offers ample space for backing up large files, multimedia projects, and critical data, making it suitable for creative professionals, photographers, and videographers alike. The drives fast transfer speeds ensure efficient data management, even when handling hefty files, ensuring you dont waste precious time waiting for data to be copied.", The inclusion of both USB-C and USB-A compatibility ensures seamless connectivity with a wide range of devices, from modern laptops to older computers, providing versatile usage options for various workflows. Moreover, the drive is bus-powered, eliminating the need for an external power source and making it a truly portable solution., One notable feature of the ArmorATD is its compatibility with the SanDisk SecureAccess encryption software, offering added protection for sensitive data. This feature provides an extra layer of security and peace of mind for users concerned about data privacy., "Although the ArmorATD excels in many aspects, its worth noting that its rugged build makes it slightly bulkier and heavier compared to regular external drives. However, this is a necessary trade-off to achieve its exceptional durability.", "In conclusion, the SanDisk Professional 5TB G-DRIVE ArmorATD stands as a reliable and resilient external hard drive that caters to the needs of professionals, adventurers, and anyone seeking a trustworthy solution for on-the-go data storage. Its rugged design, generous capacity, fast transfer speeds, and secure data encryption make it a smart investment for safeguarding your valuable data, wherever your journey takes you. Whether youre trekking through the wilderness or working on intensive multimedia projects, the ArmorATD is ready to serve as your datas sturdy fortress."

Recognized immediately and the backup process to it was easy and fairly quick; we had almost 2.5tb of data and the copy took less time that expected.  So far, working perfectly.

Review text:
"Although this ssd is incredible fast, it isnt exactly 1 tb.

I was upgrading my old ssd to a new one (both were 1tb ssds) but my old ssd was 976gb while this one was 931gb.

This causes a major issure with cloning ssd data onto the new one because you need to have the same exact space or more for a successful cloning.

I bought 3 and 2 of them were 931 and the other was 976.

Just be careful, not much you can do about it as they are all 1tb."

Review text:
An absolute complete fail of a purchase.

Even after asking the question on whether it was single sided and receiving several answers confirming that it was single-sided, the 8TB Venom8 SSD is definitely DOUBLE-sided.

The drive is loaded with chips on both sides and will not fit onto a board or system that requires a single sided drive.

Dont waste your time or money on this drive if your looking for a single sided 8TB solution.

Great form factor and a good value at the price.

I penalized it a star, though, because the included cord is only for USB-C interface.

I did not discover this until I unboxed it, and had to buy separately a USB-A to micro-B cord so that I could plug it to my desktop computer.

Review text: This drive was recommended by an IT professional so I got 2. One for home and one for at work. Over the course of a year I made 6 backups to my home computer. I WAS gonna make another back up this morning. When I plugged it in, it made a bunch of buzzing noises. It usually doesn't do that. And lo and behold my computer no longer recognizes it. Isn't that great! Not only can't I make a current backup, I can't access any of the backups I have on the drive. Oh, did I mention I spend an hour reading Seagate Support's Website and trying all their "stuff" to try and when that didn't work, I tried messaging their website for another hour and lo and behold, that got me nowhere. Go figure. So instead of spending $100 on this thing, it would have been more fun to just take $100 and flush it down the toilet, cause this drive would probably cause my toilet to clog.

Review text:
I had been using my NAT for backups.  

These would work about 70% of the time.  

For the initial run it would literally take days.  

At some point Time Machine would somehow lose track of the backup and start over.  

This would happen a couple of times a year.  

I finally broke down and bought this product.  

Wow!  

I wish I had done it sooner.  

The drive is whisper quiet and an initial backup that used to take over 2 days now takes 4 hrs.  

Highly recommended.

Review text: "At first, I was leary of purchasing an off brand external hard drive 4TB by ADATA but I read some of the reviews and thought it would be fine. When I received the ADATA 4TB external hard drive the first thing I noticed was how slow it was add any documents or files to it. It took from 10 seconds to sometimes 25 seconds. This was for every document or file I added to it. Then after 6 weeks it just stopped working and an error message came up every time on my computer saying that the external hard drive didnt connect to my computer and it couldnt be read. Do yourself a real solid and just buy an internal hard drive and install it. There are videos how to do this on YouTube. Amazon is allowing me to return this 4TB ADATA external hard drive but at a $30.00 loss. I am very unhappy about this!"

Review text: As a dedicated user of technology and someone who values data security, I recently decided to purchase multiple ADATA HD710MP 2TB External Hard Drive units in the captivating camouflage design (AHD710MP-2TU31-CCF). This review aims to share my experiences and insights into why purchasing multiple units of this external hard drive has been a transformative decision for my digital lifestyle., Robust Durability:, The ADATA HD710MP external hard drive is renowned for its rugged build quality, offering military-grade protection for my valuable data. The desire for a reliable and durable backup solution for different purposes fueled my purchase of multiple units. Whether backing up important work files, archiving cherished memories, or storing multimedia content, these drives ensure that my data remains safe from accidental drops, shocks, and water splashes., Ample Storage Capacity:, With each unit boasting a generous 2TB storage capacity, purchasing multiple ADATA HD710MP drives provides me with abundant space to organize and store my expanding digital library. The ample storage capacity allows me to seamlessly manage various data types, from documents and images to videos and applications., Versatile Compatibility:, One of the key reasons I opted to buy multiple ADATA HD710MP drives is their versatility in compatibility. These external hard drives effortlessly connect to various devices, including laptops, desktops, gaming consoles, and smart TVs. This compatibility ensures that my data is accessible whenever and wherever I need it, regardless of my device., Efficient Data Management:, "By purchasing multiple units of the ADATA HD710MP, Ive efficiently categorized and separated different types of data. I assign specific drives for work-related documents, personal files, entertainment content, and more. This organized approach streamlines my data management, saving valuable time and reducing clutter on individual devices.", Backup Redundancy:, Data loss can be catastrophic, and having multiple units of the ADATA HD710MP has given me peace of mind through redundancy. With each drive as a backup for the others, I can rest assured that my important data is safeguarded against unexpected hardware failures or corruption. This backup redundancy is invaluable, especially for crucial documents and irreplaceable memories., Portability and Aesthetics:, The camouflage design of the ADATA HD710MP adds a touch of personal style to my digital accessories. The sleek and rugged exterior appeals to my aesthetic preferences and ensures that these drives are visually distinct, making it easy to identify their specific content., Conclusion:, Purchasing multiple units of the ADATA HD710MP 2TB External Hard Drive in camouflage design has been a game-changing decision for my data management and security. The combination of robust durability, ample storage capacity, versatile compatibility, efficient data management, backup redundancy, and unique aesthetics has elevated my digital experience to new heights. These drives have become indispensable tools in my technology arsenal, and I wholeheartedly recommend them to anyone seeking reliable and stylish external storage solutions for their diverse data needs.

Review text: As a dedicated user of technology and someone who values data security, I recently decided to purchase multiple ADATA HD710MP 2TB External Hard Drive units in the captivating camouflage design (AHD710MP-2TU31-CCF). This review aims to share my experiences and insights into why purchasing multiple units of this external hard drive has been a transformative decision for my digital lifestyle., Robust Durability:, The ADATA HD710MP external hard drive is renowned for its rugged build quality, offering military-grade protection for my valuable data. The desire for a reliable and durable backup solution for different purposes fueled my purchase of multiple units. Whether backing up important work files, archiving cherished memories, or storing multimedia content, these drives ensure that my data remains safe from accidental drops, shocks, and water splashes., Ample Storage Capacity:, With each unit boasting a generous 2TB storage capacity, purchasing multiple ADATA HD710MP drives provides me with abundant space to organize and store my expanding digital library. The ample storage capacity allows me to seamlessly manage various data types, from documents and images to videos and applications., Versatile Compatibility:, One of the key reasons I opted to buy multiple ADATA HD710MP drives is their versatility in compatibility. These external hard drives effortlessly connect to various devices, including laptops, desktops, gaming consoles, and smart TVs. This compatibility ensures that my data is accessible whenever and wherever I need it, regardless of my device., Efficient Data Management:, "By purchasing multiple units of the ADATA HD710MP, Ive efficiently categorized and separated different types of data. I assign specific drives for work-related documents, personal files, entertainment content, and more. This organized approach streamlines my data management, saving valuable time and reducing clutter on individual devices.", Backup Redundancy:, Data loss can be catastrophic, and having multiple units of the ADATA HD710MP has given me peace of mind through redundancy. With each drive as a backup for the others, I can rest assured that my important data is safeguarded against unexpected hardware failures or corruption. This backup redundancy is invaluable, especially for crucial documents and irreplaceable memories., Portability and Aesthetics:, The camouflage design of the ADATA HD710MP adds a touch of personal style to my digital accessories. The sleek and rugged exterior appeals to my aesthetic preferences and ensures that these drives are visually distinct, making it easy to identify their specific content., Conclusion:, Purchasing multiple units of the ADATA HD710MP 2TB External Hard Drive in camouflage design has been a game-changing decision for my data management and security. The combination of robust durability, ample storage capacity, versatile compatibility, efficient data management, backup redundancy, and unique aesthetics has elevated my digital experience to new heights. These drives have become indispensable tools in my technology arsenal, and I wholeheartedly recommend them to anyone seeking reliable and stylish external storage solutions for their diverse data needs.

Review text:
The drive failed in under 2 years.  

Constantly wakes in the middle of the night for a 10 min spin.  

I own 4.  

One of the other ones is the slowest drive I ever owned.  

When I open the photo app on my mac it takes about 5 mins to load the pictures.  

I replaced it with an SSD and it take less than 2 seconds now.

Review text: "Experience the power of reliable and secure storage with the WD 4TB My Book Desktop External Hard Drive. With a spacious 4TB capacity, this external HDD provides ample space for all your important files and backups. The USB 3.0 interface ensures fast data transfer speeds. Review text: The ONLY reason I bought a My Book was to get the in-house software included to keep consistent, reliable backups.  Free software for backing up files is a really sketchy market and none have performed for me so I incurred extra expense and went with a WD My Book to get that feature.  I was having trouble installing "WD Backup" software from their "WD Discovery" app so I went on the website to download it directly., I was shocked to see that next to the software install it said "WD Backup (Support for WD Backup has ended. Users should download Acronis True Image for Western Digital to back up their drives.)" This is only a 5 year license for this separate software solution so basically I bought a backup drive that only lasts for 5 years as I'll be damned if I pay for software after paying a premium for a full-package drive like this.  I can still download the old software "WD Backup" but if it isn't supported how long will it work even?  So stressful., Shame on you WD! (Screenshots are directly from their website.)

Review text:
Bought this product as a gift for someone who plays Xbox and ran out of storage.

They hooked it up and transferred all of their games over and it worked perfectly fine for 2 weeks

and then he was getting notifications from his Xbox saying that the games that had been transferred were corrupted.

After spending hours retrieving the games and redownloading them to the internal drive he finally got to play them again with no issues.

Not worth the $40 for 2 weeks worth.

I do not recommend.

Review text:
I copied 13 gigs of video from my SSD to the 160 (149) gig drive in about five minutes.

So I think the claim "backup massive data in seconds" is a bit hyperbole.

But that's still pretty fast.

And as many reviewers here have mentioned, the cable is far, FAR too short.

There is also a noticeable clicking which is a tell-tale of imminent/eventual failure and data loss.

Doesnt last as long as there Three-year warranty.

Going to try another brand.

Review text:
"Though the instructions are slim-to-none and require a magnifying glass to read, and though I have an older OS (Windows 7), this is a totally plug-and-play external drive.

Windows 7 popped up with a message that it couldnt find a driver for it, but it didnt matter because the drive works regardless.

Dont worry about the tiny instructions and ignore Windows.

The drive does precisely what its supposed to do."

Review text:
Just received the 1 TB MegaZ Hard drive this morning and it is working great with my Mac.  

So far I transferred a bunch of pictures from my Macs hard drive to the MegaZ.  I am able to open the pictures up.  

It came formatted with ExFat format, so I can use it with my Mac and it also will work on a a Windows PC without having to reformat it.  

I am only giving it 5 stars, because I dont know how it will work in the long run.

Review text:
The information provided for the product gives the impression that all you have to do is plug in it to your computer and back-up miraculously happens.  

Not so.  

It's pretty simple, but you have to go to your control panel, find backup and restore, and order the backup to go to the unit (is was "D" on mine).
